text: 8點. 8點. Fiction Teachers, what is it called, Seminar, Institute at the University of Kansas. And James Gunn was one of the ... Oh, here's Jim Bain, raise your hand. She's gonna tell you a little bit about the history of the play. She's one of the authors of it. And then I'm going to introduce the cast, and we're going to get started. This summer at the third annual Intensive English Institute on the Teaching of Science Fiction. And if you think the title was bad, you should have been at the course. We went to class from 9 o'clock in the morning until 9 o'clock in the evening for three weeks. And we got a little crazy. Like this t-shirt. And like this story. Two of the books on the reading list were James Gunn's The Road to Science Fiction 1 and 2. And when it came time to title our story, it seemed perfectly natural to just extend his metaphor. Because this story really is stuck on the shoulder of the road. We also of course had to include Jim Gunn's campus in the story. as well as set it in Kansas where the class took place. And also Steve Goldman was one of the teachers besides Jim Gunn and they spent three weeks debating whether or not JG Ballard wrote science fiction. Naturally, we got tired of hearing it so JG Ballard became our villain and the debate was the subject of our story. We also got a little crazy with the punning. That's it. Stuck on the shoulder of the road to science fiction. In case you were wondering, the frisking at the door was to make sure none of you were carrying anything throwable. Both of them. From that side to this in the cast, we have beautiful but dumb, who is Cliff Flint. Cliff, you're going to have to speak up. You've got such a delicate voice. Pat Buchanan is our lovely science fiction writer called Stela Idea. Closer to the mic? Okay. Next we have our guest of honor, Marianne Mueller, and she is the wonderful mad scientist, Dr. Loom. Tell them what Dr. Loom's first name is. She doesn't have one. Yes, she does. It's Fruit of The, isn't it? Oh, that's him. You'll get the references. And next to Mary is Mark Bernstein, and he is our villain, J.G. This is called casting against type, of course. Ha. And our narrator, Meg Cadleth. And I'm Susie, and I'm Teela Brown, and I don't know what that is. Teela Brown? You were lucky to get some of that. Oh, gee. Can we get some more quarterbacks? Oh I'm sorry. Sound effects by Nancy Tucker and they were all her idea I had nothing to do with that. Stuck on the shoulder of the road to science fiction. In a small and cluttered laboratory in Erwan, Kansas, Doctor Loom, a frizzy haired, absent-minded, thick-lensed, white-jacketed, ever-so-slightly-mad scientist, is conducting experiments. Bursting into the room, a beautiful but dumb young man, B.B.D., skips up to the doctor. Hey, Willman, you're so smart. I wish I could understand your invention. Don't worry, your pretty little head about it, my sweet little papaya. Why don't you read your comic book? Dr. Lume turns back to the sparking panel, while BBD, waiting a few moments to be sure the conversation has ended, tiptoes gingerly to the high wooden stool in the corner. The massive wooden door shakes to the beat of a loud, powerful knock. A slightly stooped, hunchbacked robot with large, protruding eyes leads in a strong, silent, but mildly aberrant science fiction writer. The robot shambles over to Dr. Loom, hands her a small white card, and retreats from the laboratory. Good afternoon, Dr. Loom. I am Stila Ideas, star reporter and brilliant science fiction writer for a stonding robotics magazine, otherwise known as ARM. I can read that on your card, young lady. However, I'm a scientific genius and very busy at the moment. I have no time to fritter away in idle conversation, so if you'll pardon me. Dr. Loom turns away. Excuse me, doctor. Have you forgotten our appointment to discuss your latest world-shattering invention? Oh, of course. Do excuse me. I have so much on my mind. Come over here and let me introduce you to Ego, the electronic gizmo orienter. Dr. Loom eagerly grabs Stela's beefy bicep and drags her toward a trapezoidal edifice of gleaming metal. Pulsing lights dot the upper third of the machine like a theater marquee on opening night. A control panel, arrayed with a dizzying assortment of dials and switches, protrudes from the center of the trapezoid. Steele's eyes are immediately drawn, however, to a cylindrical shaft setting to the right side of the machine. Two words, scrawled in orange Dayglow letters, straddle the shaft. As you probably know, Ms. Dia, it has long been my aim in life to bring all people the ineffable ecstasy I've known from reading science fiction. And I think I finally found the perfect method. From his stool in the corner, BBD has been surreptitiously glancing at the two women. Ever since Stila Idea had entered the room, BBD's heart had pounded frantically and his sculptured hands had perspired. This humble machine you see before you has the power to alter mainstream fiction by introducing a disjunctive element into the story, thus changing mundane literature into its highest form, science fiction! But how does it work, Doctor? The Doctor launches into a long technical explanation, which confuses Steela and totally baffles BBD. Do you mean to say that all I have to do is push this lever to activate the machine? Oh, no, no, don't touch that. The lever moves both ways. if you push it towards the word dis, ego will change mundane literature to science fiction. But, if the lever is in the dis, dis position, science fiction loses its disjunct development and becomes mundane. Heaven forbid, Doctor, that anyone would ever do such a dastardly deed. At that moment, the robot appears in the doorway with an apologetic expression on its chrome face and informs Dr. Loom that an urgent message has just arrived from Senator Proxmire. With an exasperated shake of her frizzy head, Dr. Loom leaves, followed by her faithful robot. Stila, left to her own devices, begins examining the lab, carefully avoiding contact with the crucial lever. She scans the rack of test tubes, smoking vials, and moldy Petri dishes. Suddenly, it is as if there were a spark from across the room Two pairs of eyes meet, and for a moment, time stops BBD slowly rises from his stool, the comic book slipping from his grasp Stila rushes forward to retrieve the magazine Pardon me, I think you've dropped this Stila glances at the cover Gosh, are you a Duck Dodgers fan too? BBD blushes prettily You'll never believe this, but I have an exquisite collection of Duck Dodgers holograms in my apartment. If you are free tonight, perhaps I could show them to you. Gee, I'd love to, but I'm not sure my mother would approve. She doesn't have to know. Leave the alley door unlocked, and I'll meet you here tonight. Okay. Later that night, BBD impatiently paces in the laboratory. A soft scuffling sound from the alley attracts his attention. He throws open the door and finds himself face to face with a sinister figure Little does he know that the tall, skinny, leather-booted, black-caped man wearing a wide-brimmed hat which tilts over his face revealing only a Fu Manchu mustache is the diabolical J.G. B.B.D. faints With animal cunning, J.G. lifts the crumpled body and staggers into the alley where waits a large but dumpy mushroom-shaped vehicle. Across the side of the ship are stenciled the words Chi-Chi Engineers Ringworld Kansas. J.G. flings the limp body into the craft and clangs shut the door. He slinks back to the laboratory. Once inside, he is instinctively drawn toward Ego. He studies the control panel for a moment, then begins to manipulate dials and switches. Meanwhile, back outside, our unsuspecting heroine strides confidently toward the laboratory door. With a keen glance, she takes note of the unusual vehicle parked inconveniently in the alley. Mildly annoyed, she circles it. She gently pushes the laboratory door open. J.G., who hears the hinges creak, whips around only to find himself confronting the cool, clear eyes of Stila Idea. Who are you and what are you doing? I'm a maintenance representative of Serviceable Pros, Inc. I'm doing a monthly service check on the disjunctor. Oh, well, have you seen Mr. Loom's son, B.B.D.? No, and if you'll excuse me, I must be going. Flipping through a copy of Duck Dodger's, Steela hears a rumble in the alley. It suddenly hits her. That's funny. That ship belonged to a different company. Who was that caped man? Stilo rushes outside and sees the mushroom-shaped ship dwindling in the distance She jumps into a bright red roadster and races after it through the gateway, over the mainstream across the campus, over the river and through the woods to the sinister Castle Harlan Meanwhile, back at the laboratory, a voice filters down from upstairs Is that you, my little cantaloupe? Little does Dr. Loom know, but her little cantaloupe is at this moment lying unconscious at the feet of the evil J.G. Curses! I didn't have time to alter ego And now that meddling fool has followed me here I've got to take care of her At this moment, BBD regains consciousness and jumps to his feet I recognize you You are J.G., my mother's arch enemy Yes, you naive little fool For years, your mother and I have been competing for control of fiction As soon as I can get rid of that meddler I will use your mother's machine for my own ends But what's going to happen to me? You will stay here and do as you're told, if you know what's good for you. J.G. stalks off the ship, locking the door behind him. Confused and bewildered, B.B.D. flings himself across the control board and begins to cry. The ship rumbles. B.B.D. is thrust to the floor by the force of the acceleration. In a matter of seconds, the ship's engines grind to a halt. With a sob, B.B.D. faints. while all this has been happening Stila somehow manages to find a seldom used secret door to castle Harland she stealthily descends the cold damp stairs and arrives at a dimly lit passageway light streams through an open door at the far end of the corridor Stila creeps toward the door cautiously she steps inside she stares for a moment at the white padded walls of the tiny cubicle directly opposite the door the wall is lined with dusty shelves holding a plethora of bottles and in some of the bottles are things the door slams shut the room is plunged into darkness meanwhile back at the laboratory dr. Loom is frantically searching for BBD at her wit's end she turns to Ego for help. if I can only orient ego to the brainwave pattern of BBD? Perhaps he can locate my missing little grape cluster. Almost instantaneously, a signal light flashes. The speaker emits a small, frightened voice. Aye? Could it be? Back at Castle Harlan, Steele pounds at the locked door. A voice booms from somewhere above her. I hope you enjoy your stay. It will be a long one. Feel free to sample my wine collection. You really must try the Amontillado. What have you... What have you done with BBD? But there is no answer. Only the fading echo of demonic laughter. For the love of God, Montresor! In a fit of emptification, Steelers sweeps a row of bottles off the shelf. By a fortuitous coincidence, her fingers brush against a hidden switch. The door swings open. She is free. At this moment, in the laboratory, the small, frightened voice cries out. Still? Our scientific genius adjusts numerous dials, frantically attempting to pinpoint her son's position. Bursting through the door with a robot at her heels, Stila confronts Dr. Loom. What's going on around here? That's what I'd like to know, young lady. After lengthy but hurried explanations, Dr. Loom and Stela agree that Ego is their only hope. We need only one more coordinate to be able to triangulate BBD's position. At that very moment, the small voice cries out again. Live? Within a matter of seconds, Ego fixes his position. Armed with this information, Dr. Loom and Stela rush to the experimental FTL ship parked in a silo behind the laboratory. Dr. Loom works the controls, and the ship hurtles into outer space. Where are we going? To the Crab Nebula. If ego is right, we may have seen the last of BBD. What do you mean? Don't you know? The center of the Crab Nebula is a black hole. Stila gasps. By the time Dr. Loom finishes explaining black holes to Stila, they have arrived. Stila activates the view screen. Where is he? Do you see that speck out there? He is orbiting the black hole. There isn't much time. The two women stare at each other in consternation. Suddenly, a spacesuited figure riding a lumbering, multi-legged beast appears. An expert in alien biology, Steela recognizes it as a galloping coincidence. A voice crackles over the speaker. Who are you guys, anyway? And what are you doing here? This is Dr. Loon, scientific genius. We are on an urgent rescue mission to save my son from being captured by the black hole. Who are you? Oh, I'm Tila Brown, and by a stroke of luck, I may be able to help you. Do you have any ruby red slippers aboard? Why, I'm wearing some. Listen carefully, then. Close your eyes And click your heels together three times Whispering the words Come to me, my melancholy baby Breathlessly, Stela follows the instructions to the letter Instantaneously, BBD appears at her side Their reunion is brief, but poignant Answering their pressing questions BBD recounts his conversation with J.G. That diabolical fiend, he must be stopped. J.G. has not been idle during the rescue operation. Short-circuiting the robot, he has gained entrance to the laboratory once more, where he is now in the process of carrying out his evil scheme. Fearing the worst, Steela and company rush back to the lab. Alas, they are too late. With a flick of the switch, J.G. sets the machinery into motion. Nothing can stop it now. In libraries and bookstores across the world, the machine begins subverting science fiction. Dying inside becomes death of a salesman. Babel 17 turns into Tristam Shandy. Dune is changed into Lawrence of Arabia. Ringworld becomes the story of O. And the world of Nalé is transformed into the Scarlet Letter. But then ego encounters the work of J.G. Billard. The machinery begins to hum and whine. Sparks fly from the circuit panels. The metal grows hotter and hotter and the machine begins to tremble and rock. Is J.G. Billard a science fiction writer? "'Tis twilight, and the machine stops." Thank you, people. It is now — you appreciate it.

Good afternoon, Dr. Loom.
I am Stila Ideas, star reporter and brilliant science fiction writer for a stonding robotics magazine, otherwise known as ARM.
I can read that on your card, young lady.
However, I'm a scientific genius and very busy at the moment.
I have no time to fritter away in idle conversation, so if you'll pardon me.

Excuse me, doctor. Have you forgotten our appointment to discuss your latest world-shattering invention?

Come over here and let me introduce you to Ego, the electronic gizmo orienter.
Dr. Loom eagerly grabs Stela's beefy bicep and drags her toward a trapezoidal edifice of gleaming metal.

As you probably know, Ms. Dia,
it has long been my aim in life
to bring all people the ineffable ecstasy
I've known from reading science fiction.
And I think I finally found the perfect method.
From his stool in the corner,
BBD has been surreptitiously glancing at the two women.
Ever since Stila Idea had entered the room,
BBD's heart had pounded frantically
and his sculptured hands had perspired.
This humble machine you see before you
has the power to alter mainstream fiction
by introducing a disjunctive element into the story,
thus changing mundane literature into its highest form, science fiction!
But how does it work, Doctor?
The Doctor launches into a long technical explanation,
which confuses Steela and totally baffles BBD.
Do you mean to say that all I have to do is push this lever to activate the machine?
Oh, no, no, don't touch that.
The lever moves both ways.
if you push it towards the word dis,

science fiction loses its disjunct development and becomes mundane.

With an exasperated shake of her frizzy head, Dr. Loom leaves,
followed by her faithful robot.
Stila, left to her own devices, begins examining the lab,
carefully avoiding contact with the crucial lever.
She scans the rack of test tubes, smoking vials, and moldy Petri dishes.
Suddenly, it is as if there were a spark from across the room
Two pairs of eyes meet, and for a moment, time stops

Stila rushes forward to retrieve the magazine
Pardon me, I think you've dropped this
Stila glances at the cover
Gosh, are you a Duck Dodgers fan too?
BBD blushes prettily
You'll never believe this, but I have an exquisite collection of Duck Dodgers holograms in my apartment.
If you are free tonight, perhaps I could show them to you.
Gee, I'd love to, but I'm not sure my mother would approve.
She doesn't have to know.
Leave the alley door unlocked, and I'll meet you here tonight.
Okay.
Later that night, BBD impatiently paces in the laboratory.
A soft scuffling sound from the alley attracts his attention.
He throws open the door and finds himself face to face with a sinister figure
Little does he know that the tall, skinny, leather-booted, black-caped man
wearing a wide-brimmed hat which tilts over his face
revealing only a Fu Manchu mustache
is the diabolical J.G.
B.B.D. faints
With animal cunning, J.G. lifts the crumpled body and staggers into the alley
where waits a large but dumpy mushroom-shaped vehicle.
Across the side of the ship are stenciled the words
Chi-Chi Engineers Ringworld Kansas.
J.G. flings the limp body into the craft
and clangs shut the door.
He slinks back to the laboratory.
Once inside, he is instinctively drawn toward Ego.
He studies the control panel for a moment,
then begins to manipulate dials and switches.
Meanwhile, back outside, our unsuspecting heroine
strides confidently toward the laboratory door.
With a keen glance, she takes note of the unusual vehicle
parked inconveniently in the alley.
Mildly annoyed, she circles it.
She gently pushes the laboratory door open.
J.G., who hears the hinges creak,
whips around only to find himself
confronting the cool, clear eyes of Stila Idea.
Who are you and what are you doing?
I'm a maintenance representative of Serviceable Pros, Inc.
I'm doing a monthly service check on the disjunctor.
Oh, well, have you seen Mr. Loom's son, B.B.D.?
No, and if you'll excuse me, I must be going.
Flipping through a copy of Duck Dodger's,
Steela hears a rumble in the alley.
It suddenly hits her.
That's funny.
That ship belonged to a different company.
Who was that caped man?
Stilo rushes outside and sees the mushroom-shaped ship
dwindling in the distance
She jumps into a bright red roadster
and races after it
through the gateway, over the mainstream
across the campus, over the river and through the woods
to the sinister Castle Harlan
Meanwhile, back at the laboratory, a voice filters down from upstairs
Is that you, my little cantaloupe?
Little does Dr. Loom know, but her little cantaloupe is at this moment lying unconscious at the feet of the evil J.G.
Curses! I didn't have time to alter ego
And now that meddling fool has followed me here
I've got to take care of her
At this moment, BBD regains consciousness and jumps to his feet
I recognize you
You are J.G., my mother's arch enemy
Yes, you naive little fool
For years, your mother and I have been competing for control of fiction
As soon as I can get rid of that meddler
I will use your mother's machine for my own ends
But what's going to happen to me?
You will stay here and do as you're told,
if you know what's good for you.
J.G. stalks off the ship, locking the door behind him.
Confused and bewildered,
B.B.D. flings himself across the control board
and begins to cry.
The ship rumbles.
B.B.D. is thrust to the floor by the force of the acceleration.
In a matter of seconds, the ship's engines grind to a halt.
With a sob, B.B.D. faints.

little grape cluster.
Almost instantaneously,
a signal light flashes. The speaker
emits a small, frightened voice.
Aye? Could it be?
Back at Castle Harlan,
Steele pounds at the locked door.
A voice booms
from somewhere above her.
I hope you enjoy your stay.
It will be a long one.
Feel free to sample my wine collection.
You really must try the Amontillado.
What have you...
What have you done with BBD?
But there is no answer.
Only the fading echo of demonic laughter.
For the love of God, Montresor!
In a fit of emptification,
Steelers sweeps a row of bottles off the shelf.
By a fortuitous coincidence, her fingers brush against a hidden switch.
The door swings open.
She is free.
At this moment, in the laboratory, the small, frightened voice cries out.
Still?
Our scientific genius adjusts numerous dials, frantically attempting to pinpoint her son's position.
Bursting through the door with a robot at her heels, Stila confronts Dr. Loom.
What's going on around here?
That's what I'd like to know, young lady.
After lengthy but hurried explanations,
Dr. Loom and Stela agree that Ego is their only hope.
We need only one more coordinate
to be able to triangulate BBD's position.
At that very moment, the small voice cries out again.
Live?
Within a matter of seconds, Ego fixes his position.
Armed with this information,
Dr. Loom and Stela rush to the experimental FTL ship
parked in a silo behind the laboratory.
Dr. Loom works the controls,
and the ship hurtles into outer space.
Where are we going?
To the Crab Nebula.
If ego is right, we may have seen the last of BBD.
What do you mean?
Don't you know?
The center of the Crab Nebula is a black hole.
Stila gasps.
By the time Dr. Loom finishes explaining black holes to Stila, they have arrived.
Stila activates the view screen.
Where is he?
Do you see that speck out there?
He is orbiting the black hole.
There isn't much time.
The two women stare at each other in consternation.
Suddenly, a spacesuited figure riding a lumbering, multi-legged beast appears.
An expert in alien biology, Steela recognizes it as a galloping coincidence.
A voice crackles over the speaker.
Who are you guys, anyway?
And what are you doing here?
This is Dr. Loon, scientific genius.
We are on an urgent rescue mission to save my son from being captured by the black hole.
Who are you?
Oh, I'm Tila Brown, and by a stroke of luck, I may be able to help you.
Do you have any ruby red slippers aboard?
Why, I'm wearing some.
Listen carefully, then.
Close your eyes
And click your heels together three times
Whispering the words
Come to me, my melancholy baby
Breathlessly, Stela follows the instructions to the letter
Instantaneously, BBD appears at her side
Their reunion is brief, but poignant
Answering their pressing questions
BBD recounts his conversation with J.G.
That diabolical fiend, he must be stopped.
J.G. has not been idle during the rescue operation.
Short-circuiting the robot, he has gained entrance to the laboratory once more,
where he is now in the process of carrying out his evil scheme.
Fearing the worst, Steela and company rush back to the lab.
Alas, they are too late.
With a flick of the switch, J.G. sets the machinery into motion.
Nothing can stop it now.
In libraries and bookstores across the world,
the machine begins subverting science fiction.
Dying inside becomes death of a salesman.
Babel 17 turns into Tristam Shandy.
Dune is changed into Lawrence of Arabia.
Ringworld becomes the story of O.
And the world of Nalé is transformed into the Scarlet Letter.
But then ego encounters the work of J.G. Billard.
The machinery begins to hum and whine.
Sparks fly from the circuit panels.
The metal grows hotter and hotter and the machine begins to tremble and rock.
Is J.G. Billard a science fiction writer?
"'Tis twilight, and the machine stops."
Thank you, people.
It is now —
you appreciate it.
